_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Control room process monitors; Regular operator rounds
_prev_prog_3.Description: The ExxonMobil Joliet Refinery Operations Integrity Management System and the Process Safety Management Manual describe the programs that are in place to address OSHA's 29 CFR 1910.119 Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals (PSM) and EPA's 40 CFR 68 Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions (Risk Management Plans-RMP).  The general prevention program consists of elements addressing process safety information, process hazard analysis, operating procedures, training, mechanical integrity, management of change, pre-startup safety review, compliance audits, incident investigation, employee participation, hot work permits and contractors.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
p chemical release scenarios that estimate the potential community impact from an accidental release.  These scenarios are useful for emergency planning in the event of an accident.  There are two types of scenarios required by the EPA.  The worst case scenario (WCS) is the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance.  It assumes the worst case meteorology that would allow the release to travel the greatest distance.  The alternative release scenario (ARS) allows industries to develop a more realistic planning scenario.



The WCS and ARS for flammable chemicals at the Joliet Refinery involve the release of butane.  Off site impact is mitigated by our prevention programs listed in Section 1 above.



The WCS for toxic substances at the Joliet refinery involves the release of hydrofluoric acid.  There are two ARS for toxics at the Joliet Refinery involving the release of hydrofluoric acid and ammonia.  Off site impact is mitigated by our prevention programs listed in Section 1 above.





4.0 GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



To ensure that our risk management program is appropriately developed and implemented, our site manager has assigned the role of RMP coordinator to a staff member with the necessary background, training and experience.  The RMP coordinator, acting with the authority delegated directly from the site manager, has the responsibility for the development and implementation of our risk management program.



The Joliet Refinery has developed programs to comply with the industry's most stringent environmental, health and safety standards. Additionally, the Joliet Refinery has served as a training site for OSHA Compliance Officers attending the OSHA Training Institute in Des Plaines, Illinois.



The Joliet Refinery takes a systematic, proactive approach to prevent accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  ExxonMobil's Operations Integrity Management System (OIMS) addresses each of th

e essential features of a successful accident prevention program and includes the following elements:



? Management Leadership, Commitment, and Accountability

? Risk Assessment and Management

? Facilities Design and Construction

? Information/Documentation 

? Personnel Safety

? Occupational Health

? Personnel

? Training

? Operations and Maintenance Procedures

? Work Permits

? Critical Equipment

? Mechanical Integrity

? Environmental Protection

? Regulatory Compliance

? Operations Interface Management

? Management of Change

? Third Party Services

? Incident Investigation and Analysis

? Emergency Preparedness

? Community Awareness

? Assessment and Improvement



Our RMP uses the individual elements to prevent accidental chemical releases.



In addition to our industry leading management programs, we have designed systems and equipment to control, prevent, detect and mitigate potential accidental releases.



We employ extensive mechanical integrity and preventive maintenance programs to ensure the integrity of our equipment and safety systems.  Our mechanical integrity program uses equipment surveillance and preventive maintenance activities to identify equipment that may be deteriorating and in need of repair or replacement, before failure occurs.  This program also specifies the repairs (or parts replacement) needed to return equipment to acceptable specifications.



We train our employees to safely perform their assigned tasks.  Our training program includes initial training as well as periodic refresher training and training updates when major process or equipment changes are made.  As part of our training, we include provisions for ensuring that employees understand the training, including written tests and field demonstrations.





5.0 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The Joliet Refinery has had only one accidental release of a regulated flammable substance from a RMP covered process within the last five (5) years that met the reporting cri

teria.  The accidental release occurred when the Coker Main Fractionator PSVs lifted to the atmosphere.  At the time of the event, B-Drum was in the water (cooling) portion of the decoking cycle and over-pressured, relieving to the Main Fractionator.  Consequently, the Main Fractionator Overhead Accumulator (16-D-6) relieved to the flare, the Blowdown System relieved to the flare, and the Main Fractionator (16-D-1) relieved to the atmosphere.  The release impacted the public with both hydrocarbon odors and oil misting offsite.  



There were two factors leading to the drum over-pressure. The first was the water addition rate during the cooling cycle. The second was the presence of an area of encapsulated coke, which was created due to an atypical temperature profile during the heating process in the drum cycle.  Following this incident, changes have been made to the site coke drum cooling water and drum heat-up procedures.  





6.0 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The Joliet Refinery's emergency response plan serves as a line of defense against accidental releases and other emergencies and the procedure for reacting to unwanted releases and other emergencies if they occur.  The Joliet Refinery maintains an emergency responder brigade of approximately one hundred employee volunteers.  We also maintain a state certified fire academy on-site.  The Joliet Refinery maintains a written emergency response plan at the facility and is included in the community response plan.  The Joliet Refinery coordinates its emergency response drills with the local emergency responders, the Will County Emergency Management Agency, local hospitals, and various other government agencies.



7.0 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Joliet Refinery is continually improving our safety programs through rigorous internal and external reviews of the Operating Integrity Management System.
